http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A unit of measure is a definite magnitude of a quantity, defined and adopted by convention or by law. It is used as a standard for measurement of the same quantity, where any other value of the quantity can be expressed as a simple multiple of the unit. For example, length is a quantity; the metre is a unit of length that represents a definite predetermined length. When we say 10 metre (or 10 m), we actually mean 10 times the definite predetermined length called "metre".
This property links an entity to a numerical value.
This property links an entity to a om:Unit instance.

The class skos:Concept is the class of SKOS concepts.

A SKOS concept can be viewed as an idea or notion; a unit of thought. However, what constitutes a unit of thought is subjective, and this definition is meant to be suggestive, rather than restrictive.

The notion of a SKOS concept is useful when describing the conceptual or intellectual structure of a knowledge organization system, and when referring to specific ideas or meanings established within a KOS.

Note that, because SKOS is designed to be a vehicle for representing semi-formal KOS, such as thesauri and classification schemes, a certain amount of flexibility has been built in to the formal definition of this class.
A temporal interval or instant.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A temporal interval or instant.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A derivation is a transformation of an entity into another, an update of an entity resulting in a new one, or the construction of a new entity based on a pre-existing entity.

Influence is the capacity of an entity, activity, or agent to have an effect on the character, development, or behavior of another by means of usage, start, end, generation, invalidation, communication, derivation, attribution, association, or delegation.
An actuatable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: An actuatable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: A window actuator acts by changing the state between a frame and a window. The ability of the window to be opened and closed is its ActuatableProperty.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: An Actuation carries out an (Actuation) Procedure to change the state of the world using an Actuator.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: An Actuation carries out an (Actuation) Procedure to change the state of the world using an Actuator.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: The activity of automatically closing a window if the temperature in a room drops below 20 degree Celsius. The activity is the Actuation and the device that closes the window is the Actuator. The Procedure is the rule, plan, or specification that defines the conditions that triggers the Actuation, here a drop in temperature.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A device that is used by, or implements, an (Actuation) Procedure that changes the state of the world.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A device that is used by, or implements, an (Actuation) Procedure that changes the state of the world.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: A window actuator for automatic window control, i.e., opening or closing the window.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: When measuring the height of a tree, the height is the observed ObservableProperty, 20m may be the Result of the Observation, and the tree is the FeatureOfInterest. A window is a FeatureOfInterest for an automatic window control Actuator.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: An observable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: An observable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: The height of a tree, the depth of a water body, or the temperature of a surface are examples of observable properties, while the value of a classic car is not (directly) observable but asserted.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Observation - Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to a Sensor to describe what made the Observation and how; links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that property was associated with.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to a Sensor to describe what made the Observation and how; links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that property was associated with.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: The activity of estimating the intensity of an Earthquake using the Mercalli intensity scale is an Observation as is measuring the moment magnitude, i.e., the energy released by said earthquake.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A Platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly Sensors, Actuators, Samplers, and other Platforms.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A Platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly Sensors, Actuators, Samplers, and other Platforms.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: A post, buoy, vehicle, ship, aircraft, satellite, cell-phone, human or animal may act as platforms for (technical or biological) sensors or actuators.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: The value 20 as the height of a certain tree together with the unit, e.g., Meter.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A Sample is the result from an act of Sampling.
Feature which is intended to be representative of a FeatureOfInterest on which Observations may be made.
Physical samples are sometimes known as 'specimens'.

Samples are artifacts of an observational strategy, and have no significant function outside of their role in the observation process. The characteristics of the samples themselves are of little interest, except perhaps to the manager of a sampling campaign.

A Sample is intended to sample some FatureOfInterest, so there is an expectation of at least one isSampleOf property. However, in some cases the identity, and even the exact type, of the sampled feature may not be known when observations are made using the sampling features.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Feature which is intended to be representative of a FeatureOfInterest on which Observations may be made.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: A 'station' is essentially an identifiable locality where a sensor system or Procedure may be deployed and an observation made. In the context of the observation model, it connotes the 'world in the vicinity of the station', so the observed properties relate to the physical medium at the station, and not to any physical artifact such as a mooring, buoy, benchmark, monument, well, etc.

A statistical sample is often designed to be characteristic of an entire population, so that observations can be made regarding the sample that provide a good estimate of the properties of the population.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A transient sample, such as a ships-track or flight-line, might be identified and described, but is unlikely to be revisited exactly.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: Accelerometers, gyroscopes, barometers, magnetometers, and so forth are Sensors that are typically mounted on a modern smart phone (which acts as Platform). Other examples of sensors include the human eyes.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between an Actuation and the property of a FeatureOfInterest it is acting upon.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an Actuation and the property of a FeatureOfInterest it is acting upon.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: In the activity (Actuation) of automatically closing a window if the temperature in a room drops below 20 degrees Celsius, the property on which the Actuator acts upon is the state of the window as it changes from being open to being closed.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A relation between an Observation and the entity whose quality was observed, or between an Actuation and the entity whose property was modified, or between an act of Sampling and the entity that was sampled.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A relation between an Observation and the entity whose quality was observed, or between an Actuation and the entity whose property was modified, or between an act of Sampling and the entity that was sampled.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: For example, in an Observation of the weight of a person, the FeatureOfInterest is the person and the property is its weight.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation linking an Observation and a Sensor or Actuator and a Result, which contains a value representing the value associated with the observed Property.
Relation linking an Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling and a Result or Sample.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation linking an Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling and a Result or Sample.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a FeatureOfInterest and the Sample used to represent it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a FeatureOfInterest and the Sample used to represent it.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The simple value of an Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The simple value of an Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: For instance, the values 23 or true.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a Platform and a Sensor, Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, hosted or mounted on it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a Platform and a Sensor, Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, hosted or mounted on it.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between an ActuatableProperty of a FeatureOfInterest and an Actuation changing its state.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an ActuatableProperty of a FeatureOfInterest and an Actuation changing its state.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam.@value: In the activity (Actuation) of automatically closing a window if the temperature in a room drops below 20 degrees Celsius, the property on which the Actuator acts upon is the state of the window as it changes from being open to being closed.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A relation between a FeatureOfInterest and an Observation about it, an Actuation acting on it, or an act of Sampling that sampled it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A relation between a FeatureOfInterest and an Observation about it, an Actuation acting on it, or an act of Sampling that sampled it.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a Sensor, Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, and the Platform that it is mounted on or hosted by.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a Sensor, Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, and the Platform that it is mounted on or hosted by.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between an ObservableProperty and the Sensor able to observe it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an ObservableProperty and the Sensor able to observe it.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation linking a Result to the Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling that created or caused it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation linking a Result to the Observation or Actuation or act of Sampling that created or caused it.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation from a Sample to the FeatureOfInterest that it is intended to be representative of.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation from a Sample to the FeatureOfInterest that it is intended to be representative of.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between an Actuator and the Actuation it has made.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an Actuator and the Actuation it has made.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation linking an Actuation to the Actuator that made that Actuation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation linking an Actuation to the Actuator that made that Actuation.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between an Observation and the Sensor which made the Observation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an Observation and the Sensor which made the Observation.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a Sensor and an Observation made by the Sensor.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a Sensor and an Observation made by the Sensor.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation linking an Observation to the property that was observed. The ObservableProperty should be a property of the FeatureOfInterest (linked by hasFeatureOfInterest) of this Observation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation linking an Observation to the property that was observed. The ObservableProperty should be a property of the FeatureOfInterest (linked by hasFeatureOfInterest) of this Observation.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a Sensor and an ObservableProperty that it is capable of sensing.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a Sensor and an ObservableProperty that it is capable of sensing.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The time that the Result of an Observation, Actuation or Sampling applies to the FeatureOfInterest. Not necessarily the same as the resultTime. May be an Interval or an Instant, or some other compound TemporalEntity.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time that the Result of an Observation, Actuation or Sampling applies to the FeatureOfInterest. Not necessarily the same as the resultTime. May be an Interval or an Instant, or some other compound TemporalEntity.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The result time is the instant of time when the Observation, Actuation or Sampling activity was completed.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The result time is the instant of time when the Observation, Actuation or Sampling activity was completed.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: A quality of an entity. An aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A quality of an entity. An aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implement Procedures. A System may have components, its subsystems, which are other Systems.
Relation between an entity and a Property of that entity.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between an entity and a Property of that entity.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Relation between a Property and the entity it belongs to.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Relation between a Property and the entity it belongs to.

http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/descript.@value: CASO (Context Aware System Observation) is an ontology for context aware system and observation services. Its goal is to describe all the processing of the context.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Actuation is an action that a machine or device operate.
Boundary is the limits that the State can be defined when satisfy such limits.
The result of an inference that links together a property, a state of the property and a specific time period.
Observation is the action of observing or considering something.
Property is an atrribute of a thing that can be used to characterize the thing.
A qualitative data which changes over time, summarizing a set of information.
numeric value of a boundary
Relation between a caso:State and another caso:State. The first State is greater than the second State in the sense of qualitative or chronological.
Relation between a caso:State and another caso:State. The first State is greater than or equal to the second State in the sense of qualitative or chronological.

Relation linking a caso:State and a caso:Boundary. The caso:Boundary contains a value representing an lower boundary of a state. An entity is at this state when its considering value is superior or equal to the lower boundary value.

Relation linking a caso:State and a caso:Boundary. The caso:Boundary contains a value representing an upper boundary of a state. An entity is at this state when its considering value is inferior or equal to the upper boundary value.

Relation linking a caso:State and a caso:Boundary. The caso:Boundary contains a value representing an lower boundary of a state. An entity is at this state when its considering value is superior to the lower boundary value.

Relation linking a caso:State and a caso:Boundary. The caso:Boundary contains a value representing an upper boundary of a state. An entity is at this state when its considering value is inferior to the upper boundary value.
Relation between a caso:Deduction and a caso:State. The caso:Deduction has a result in the form of a  caso:State.
Relation between a caso:Property and caso:State of the Property
A deduction links an entity to a state during this temporal entity. A temporal entity could be an interval or an instant depending of the use-case.
Relation between a caso:State and another caso:State. The first State is lesser than the second State in the sense of qualitative or chronological.
Relation between a caso:State and another caso:State. The first State is lesser than or equal to the second State in the sense of qualitative or chronological.
Relation between a caso:Actuation and a saref:Function. The caso:Actuation trigger the operation of a saref:Function.
A device responsible for moving or controlling a mechanism or system by performing an actuating function

A directive that a device must support to perform a certain function. A command may act upon a state, but does not necessarily act upon a state. For example, the ON command acts upon the ON/OFF state, but the GET command does not act upon any state, it simply gives a directive to retrieve a certain value. We propose here a list of commands that are relevant for the purpose of SAREF, but this list can be extended.

A tangible object designed to accomplish a particular task in households, common public buildings or offices. In order to accomplish this task, the device performs one or more functions. For example, a washing machine is designed to wash (task) and to accomplish this task it performs a start and stop function. Devices can be structured in categories (subclasses) that reflect the different domain in which a device is used, e.g., smart appliances domain (subclass FunctionRelated) vs. building domain (subclass BuildingRelated) vs. smart grid domain (subclass EnergyRelated). New categories can be defined,if needed, to reflect other differences, for example different points of view, such as the point of view of the device's user vs. the point of view of the device's manufacturer. We propose a list of devices that are relevant for the purpose of SAREF, but this list can be extended.

The functionality necessary to accomplish the task for which a Device is designed. A device can be designed to perform more than one function. Functions can be structured in categories (subclasses) that reflect different points of view, for example, considering the specific application area for which a function can be used (e.g., light, temperature, motion, heat, power, etc.), or the capability that a function can support (e.g., receive, reply, notify, etc.), and so forth.

A device that detects and responds to events or changes in the physical environment such as light, motion, or temperature changes. Further, a device of category saref:Sensor that performs a saref:SensingFunction.
A relationship between an entity (such as a function) and a command
A relationship identifying the type of function of a device
A relationship between a command and a function.
